elements.content: Nanostructures such as nanosheets, nanotubes, nanocages, and fullerenes have been extensively studied as potential candidates in various fields since the advancement of nanoscience. Herein, the interaction between biguanides (BGN) and metformin (MET) on the modified covalent organic framework (COF), COF-B, and COF-Al was investigated using density functional theory at the ωB97XD/6-311+G (d, p) level of computation to explore a new drug delivery system. The electronic properties evaluation reveals that the studied surfaces are suited for the delivery of both drug molecules. The calculated adsorption energies and basis set superposition errors (BSSE) ranged between −21.20 and −65.86 kJ/mol. The negative values obtained are an indication of excellent interaction between the drug molecules and the COF surfaces. Moreover, BGN is better adsorbed on COF-B with E ads of −65.86 kJ/mol, while MET is better adsorbed on COF-Al with E ads = −47.30 kJ/mol. The analysis of the quantum theory of atom in molecules (QTAIM) explained the nature and strength of intermolecular interaction existing between the drug molecules BGN and MET with the adsorbing surfaces. The analysis of noncovalent interaction (NCI) shows a weak hydrogen-bond interaction. Other properties such as quantum chemical descriptors and natural bond orbital (NBO) analysis also agree with the potential of COF surfaces as drug delivery systems. The electron localization function (ELF) is discussed, and it confirms the transitions occurring in the NBO analysis of the complexes. In conclusion, COF-B and COF-Al are suitable candidates for the effective delivery of BGN and MET.

elements.content: According to the International Diabetes Federation (IDF), the global prevalence of diabetes mellitus in 2011 was 366 million, with a projected increase to 552 million by 2030. Diabetes affected an estimated 463 million people worldwide (8.8% of the adult population) in 2019, with type 2 diabetes accounting for roughly 90% of cases. It became clear in the second half of the twentieth century that a steady rise in Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) was afflicting not only the developed but also the developing world. Diabetes is a group of metabolic disorders characterized by a persistently high blood sugar level (hyperglycemia). Diabetes, if left untreated, can lead to a variety of health complications. Diabetes more than doubles a person’s risk of dying young. Furthermore, the impact of various diabetes medications, such as those which belong to the family of biguanides, for example, metformin, are under examination of the possible risks and dangers they pose. show a graphical representation of biguanide and metformin, which are widely used in the pharmaceutical industry. Biguanides have been used for the treatment of T2DM, with the most common side effects being diarrhea and dyspepsia, which occur in up to 30% of patients who take biguanides. Also, biguanide causes mitochondrial toxicity leading to lactic acidosis. Various biguanide derivatives are used as antidiabetic agents such as metformin, phenformin, and buformin. Metformin (C4H11N5) (MF) belongs to the biguanide family, which is mostly recommended for first line therapy for type 2 diabetes. The use of metformin reduces body weight in people with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Chronic liver disease is a side effect associated with metformin intake. Hypoglycemia and other side effects are possible when metformin is combined with other drugs (combination therapy). Metformin is associated with a very low incidence of lactic acidosis because it does not undergo liver metabolism and, as a result, there are no high-risk groups with impaired metabolic handling.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

According to the International Diabetes Federation (IDF), the global prevalence of diabetes mellitus in 2011 was 366 million, with a projected increase to 552 million by 2030. Diabetes affected an estimated 463 million people worldwide (8.8% of the adult population) in 2019, with type 2 diabetes accounting for roughly 90% of cases. It became clear in the second half of the twentieth century that a steady rise in Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) was afflicting not only the developed but also the developing world. Diabetes is a group of metabolic disorders characterized by a persistently high blood sugar level (hyperglycemia). Diabetes, if left untreated, can lead to a variety of health complications. Diabetes more than doubles a person's risk of dying young. Furthermore, the impact of various diabetes medications, such as those which belong to the family of biguanides, for example, metformin, are under examination of the possible risks and dangers they pose.  show a graphical representation of biguanide and metformin, which are widely used in the pharmaceutical industry. Biguanides have been used for the treatment of T2DM, with the most common side effects being diarrhea and dyspepsia, which occur in up to 30% of patients who take biguanides. Also, biguanide causes mitochondrial toxicity leading to lactic acidosis. Various biguanide derivatives are used as antidiabetic agents such as metformin, phenformin, and buformin. Metformin (C4H11N5) (MF) belongs to the biguanide family, which is mostly recommended for first line therapy for type 2 diabetes. The use of metformin reduces body weight in people with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Chronic liver disease is a side effect associated with metformin intake. Hypoglycemia and other side effects are possible when metformin is combined with other drugs (combination therapy). Metformin is associated with a very low incidence of lactic acidosis because it does not undergo liver metabolism and, as a result, there are no high-risk groups with impaired metabolic handling.

elements.content: Nanoscience has revealed a distinct and effective treatment behavior in medicine, particularly for the treatment of cancer cells. Hence, it has been highly applied in the area of drug delivery systems and tissue engineering. On the other hand, the unique characteristics, numerous varieties of COFs, including two- or three-dimensional structures, have been reported and investigated for many application areas such as gas adsorption, catalysis, optoelectronic devices, optical sensing and electrochemical sensing. Cote and colleagues developed two-dimensional (2D-COFs) and three-dimensional (3D-COFs) weaving frameworks in 2005. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are a type of porous organic structure made up of diverse covalent bonds among light elements that have tunable pore size, high crystallinity, unique molecular architecture, and a large specific surface area (e.g., H, B, C, N, and O). Because of their highly porous structures and nontoxic or heavy metal ion-free nature, one recent application area of COFs is their use as a drug delivery system. A large number of COFs have been reported in recent years, but due to their chemical stability and metal-free properties, only a few COFs have been investigated for drug uptake and release applications. Yang et al. developed 3D polyimide COFs, which are made up of pyromellitic dianhydride and 1,3,5,7-tetraamino­adamantane, respectively. Notably, this was the first time COFs were used for drug delivery, and both PI-COFs had high ibuprofen loading and well-controlled release profiles. Moreover, various drugs have been delivered using a COF applying computational approach. Computational methods are a popular tool for analyzing inclusion complexes, and they have been shown to be an efficient and effective method for assessing intermolecular interactions via noncovalent analysis, structural geometrics prediction models, and others. For this purpose, this method has been found to be effective in predicting the potentials of COFs. Ahsan et al. studied the potential of C2N for the delivery of anticancer drug fluorouracil and nitrosoureas using DFT and confirmed that both drugs can be easily delivered to their target sites based on their electronic and structural properties. Esrafili and Nurazar studied the adsorption and decomposition of methylamine (CH3NH2) on the surface of a B12N12 nanocage. Hashemzadeh and Raissi calculated the energy of interaction for a 5-Fu drug using COF values ranging from −14.497 to −50.225 kJ/mol. These findings show that 5-Fu adsorption on the COF surface occurs spontaneously, and due to the presence of a weak intermolecular interaction, the drug molecule can be easily released from the COF. Liu et al. recently investigated C2N biocompatibility and found that it does not alter the structure of proteins in cells. As a result, C2N can release the drug at the desired site and be removed from the system without causing toxicity. Gallo et al. demonstrated the adsorption of antitubercular compounds on the surface of functionalized SWCNTs and fullerenes using density functional theory.

elements.content: Liu et al. demonstrated experimentally and theoretically that C2N is highly targeted and biocompatible, causing no toxicity to normal cells before or after drug release. Anota and Cocoletzi reported the electronic and structural properties of metformin molecule on the surface and ends of (5, 5) BN nanotubes as being mostly chemisorption in nature. Metformin (MF) or the commercial hydrochloride of metformin, an oral biguanide medicine, is used in the treatment and prevention of type 2 diabetes (diabete insulin-independent). One reason for studying the COF system is to improve drug delivery conditions within the human body. In this study, we are analyzing the delivery of biguanides (BGN) and metformin (MET) on the surfaces of COF-B and COF-Al. Considering the good sensing and detection properties of COFs, we computed the geometric and electronic properties and accounted for quantum descriptors to confirm the stability of complexes formed. The inter- and intramolecular interactions are studied using second-order perturbation energies derived from natural bond orbital analysis. Quantum theory of atom in molecules (QTAIM) and noncovalent interactions (NCI) was performed to understand the nature of interaction existing between drug molecules and delivery surfaces. The region of hydrogen bond interaction, localized and delocalized electrons, is discussed using the electron localization function (ELF). The adsorption energies or interaction energies are compared after simulations of different drug orientations on the modified COF surface to determine the most stable geometry.

elements.content: The present research study computations were done with Gaussian 16, and Gauss View 6.0 was used for visualizing the molecules. The adsorption of biguanides (BGN) and metformin (MET) on the surfaces of COF-B and COF-Al is examined at different orientations, respectively. The computation of the properties and optimization of compounds are performed at ωB97XD functional with 6-311++G (d, p) basis set of DFT. Basis set 6-311++G (d, p) is preferred since it is good for final and accurate energies, though expensive. There are numerous instances in scientific reports in which researchers employed similar computational techniques to optimize drug delivery schemes owing to their dependability. ωB97XD belongs to an innovative category of density functional theory functionals called range-separated functionals, which has the ability to capture both short-range and long-range interactions, give details of charge transfer in systems, and predict weak interactions more precisely. Following the modeling of various orientations of drugs on the surfaces of COF-B and COF-Al, the interaction energies or energies of adsorption were compared to discover the geometry that had the highest stability in nature and could serve as delivery material for biguanides and metformin. The energies of adsorption (E ads) were computed using and : E a d s = E B G N / M E T @ C O F − B − ( E B G N / M E T + E C O F − B ) E a d s = E B G N / M E T @ C O F − A l − ( E B G N / M E T + E C O F − A l ) where BGN/MET@COF-B, BGN/MET@COF-Al, BGN/MET, COF-B, and COF-Al are energies of complexes formed as a result of interactions of the drugs with COF-B, COF-Al, the energies of drugs (biguanide and metformin), and energies of COF-B and COF-Al, respectively. Moreover, in order to avoid the basis set superposition error (BSSE), the exactness of interaction energy is obtained via the counterpoise method (CP). The BSSE corrected energy is computed through : E I n t − C P = E a d s − E B S S E where E ads.‑CP is counterpoised interaction energy, E ads is uncorrected energy, and E BSSE is energy after BSSE correction. Computational Methodology

The present research study computations were done with Gaussian 16, and Gauss View 6.0 was used for visualizing the molecules. The adsorption of biguanides (BGN) and metformin (MET) on the surfaces of COF-B and COF-Al is examined at different orientations, respectively. The computation of the properties and optimization of compounds are performed at ωB97XD functional with 6-311++G (d, p) basis set of DFT. Basis set 6-311++G (d, p) is preferred since it is good for final and accurate energies, though expensive. There are numerous instances in scientific reports in which researchers employed similar computational techniques to optimize drug delivery schemes owing to their dependability. ωB97XD belongs to an innovative category of density functional theory functionals called range-separated functionals, which has the ability to capture both short-range and long-range interactions, give details of charge transfer in systems, and predict weak interactions more precisely. Following the modeling of various orientations of drugs on the surfaces of COF-B and COF-Al, the interaction energies or energies of adsorption were compared to discover the geometry that had the highest stability in nature and could serve as delivery material for biguanides and metformin. The energies of adsorption (E ads) were computed using  and : 1       E   a d s   =   E   B G N / M E T @ C O F - B   -  (   E   B G N / M E T   +   E   C O F - B   )       2       E   a d s   =   E   B G N / M E T @ C O F - A l   -  (   E   B G N / M E T   +   E   C O F - A l   )     where BGN/MET@COF-B, BGN/MET@COF-Al, BGN/MET, COF-B, and COF-Al are energies of complexes formed as a result of interactions of the drugs with COF-B, COF-Al, the energies of drugs (biguanide and metformin), and energies of COF-B and COF-Al, respectively. Moreover, in order to avoid the basis set superposition error (BSSE), the exactness of interaction energy is obtained via the counterpoise method (CP). The BSSE corrected energy is computed through : 3       E   I n t - C P   =   E   a d s   -   E   B S S E      where E ads.-CP is counterpoised interaction energy, E ads is uncorrected energy, and E BSSE is energy after BSSE correction. Again, - have been employed in computing the global reactivity indices, namely chemical potential (μ), global hardness (η), global softness (S), electrophilic index (ω), and electronegativity (χ): 5     μ =    (   E   HOMO   +   E   LUMO   )    2        6     η =    (   E   LUMO   -   E   HOMO   )    2        7     S = -   1   2 η        8     ω = -     μ   2     2 η        9     χ = -    (   E   L U M O   +   E   H O M O   )    2        10       E   g   =   E   LUMO   -   E   HOMO

elements.content: The stabilization energies and the transition occurring between the complexes formed between the drug molecule and COF surfaces were estimated using the NBO 7.0 version in the Gaussian package. Furthermore, the strength and nature of interaction were determined using the quantum theory of atoms in molecules utilizing the multiwfn program. The multiwfn program was also used for the analysis of noncovalent interaction (NCI) to further confirm the nature of interaction associated with the drug molecule and COF surfaces in the study. The regions of localized and delocalized electrons for complexes, as well as the transitions formed by the electron localized function, were obtained from the multiwfn package.

elements.content: The optimized geometries of monolayer of COF-B and COF-Al are displayed in . The alternating rings of benzene and boroxine constitute the individual single layer unit of COF-B. It is made up of benzene rings connected by B3HO3 into hexagon-shaped 2D sheets that are assembled into a layered geometry. It corresponds to a proper 2D substance made up of boron, carbon, oxygen, and hydrogen. COF-B is a material with a moderately large surface due to its porosity. COF-Al is constructed by replacing the boron (B) atom in COF-B with Aluminum (Al) atom. The occurrence of oxygen atoms in six (6) boroxine rings makes the cavity of COF-B highly electronegative (4.90 eV), while COF-Al has an electronegativity value of 4.49 eV. The diameters of these oxygenated cavities range from 14.36 to 14.92 Å and 17.16 to 17.17 Å in COF-B and COF-Al, respectively. The binding sites on the porous surfaces of COF-B and COF-Al as displayed in are as follows: between the hydrogen atoms of two benzene rings (1), above the boroxine rings (2), and above benzene rings (3). Both molecules of drug are optimized in different probable directions on COF-B and COF-Al to get the most stable structures of BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B and BGN@COF-Al, MET@COF-Al complexes as presented in and .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Optimization and Energies of Interactions

The optimized geometries of monolayer of COF-B and COF-Al are displayed in . The alternating rings of benzene and boroxine constitute the individual single layer unit of COF-B. It is made up of benzene rings connected by B3HO3 into hexagon-shaped 2D sheets that are assembled into a layered geometry. It corresponds to a proper 2D substance made up of boron, carbon, oxygen, and hydrogen. COF-B is a material with a moderately large surface due to its porosity. COF-Al is constructed by replacing the boron (B) atom in COF-B with Aluminum (Al) atom. The occurrence of oxygen atoms in six (6) boroxine rings makes the cavity of COF-B highly electronegative (4.90 eV), while COF-Al has an electronegativity value of 4.49 eV. The diameters of these oxygenated cavities range from 14.36 to 14.92 Å and 17.16 to 17.17 Å in COF-B and COF-Al, respectively. The binding sites on the porous surfaces of COF-B and COF-Al as displayed in  are as follows: between the hydrogen atoms of two benzene rings (1), above the boroxine rings (2), and above benzene rings (3). Both molecules of drug are optimized in different probable directions on COF-B and COF-Al to get the most stable structures of BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B and BGN@COF-Al, MET@COF-Al complexes as presented in  and .

elements.content: The energies of interactions for BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B, BGN@COF-Al, and MET@COF-Al are −77.17 kcal/mol, −57.89 kcal/mol, −27.02 kcal/mol, and −53.07 kcal/mol, respectively, whereas the BSSE corrected energies are −65.86 kcal/mol, −50.99 kcal/mol, −21.20 kcal/mol, and −47.30 kcal/mol, respectively (). The interaction energy values demonstrate that all drugs have satisfactorily high stability with the frameworks. The interaction of biguanide with COF-B is considerably stronger than that of metformin with COF-B. This is as a result of the smaller molecule of biguanide, which best fits into the smaller oxygenated cavity of COF-B as compared to the larger size of COF-Al, while the interaction of biguanide with COF-Al is considerably weaker than that of metformin with COF-Al. We can stress that this resulted due to the unfitted nature of biguanide on the bigger oxygenated cavity of COF-Al as compared to the smaller size of COF-B. Conversely, reported adsorption energies are higher than that by Akyuz: −13.18 kcal/mol, −11.29 kcal/mol for carboplatin delivery on COF surfaces. The interaction energies of the most stable orientation for NU@C2N and FU@C2N are −26.4 kcal/mol and −26.3 kcal/mol, respectively, while the BSSE corrected energies are −20.6 kcal/mol and −20.3 kcal/mol, respectively. The values of interaction energies show that both drugs have sufficiently high stability with the surface. The interaction of nitrosourea is slightly stronger than that of fluorouracil according to Lui et al. and Ahsan et al. with interaction energies of −20.6 kcal/mol and −20.3 kcal/mol, respectively, for the delivery of fluorouracil and nitrosourea on C2N surface (see ).

As shown in and , the stable structure of BGN@COF-B indicates that one hydrogen atom (H30) of COF-B interacted with the nitrogen atom (N107) of the BGN at a distance of 4.23 Å, while the hydrogen atom (H105) of BGN interacted with the carbon atom (C58) of COF-B at a distance of 2.56 Å. Likewise, the hydrogen atom (H30) of COF-B interacted with two hydrogen atoms (H108, H114) of MET at distances of 2.25 and 2.47 Å, respectively, whereas the hydrogen atom (H114) of MET interacted with the oxygen atom (O98) of COF-B at a distance of 2.31 Å. The H117 of MET interacts with the H50 of COF-B cavity at a distance of 2.51 Å. Despite the fact that MET has more sites of interactions with the surface, the adsorption energy is less than that of BGN. This is due to the fact that BGN@COF-B is a comparatively more stable complex than the MET@COF-B complex.

Likewise, the hydrogen atom (H30) of COF-B interacted with two hydrogen atoms (H108, H114) of MET at distances of 2.25 and 2.47 Å, respectively, whereas the hydrogen atom (H114) of MET interacted with the oxygen atom (O98) of COF-B at a distance of 2.31 Å. The H117 of MET interacts with the H50 of COF-B cavity at a distance of 2.51 Å. Despite the fact that MET has more sites of interactions with the surface, the adsorption energy is less than that of BGN. elements.content: As displayed in and , the stable structure of BGN@COF-Al reveals that one hydrogen atom (H44) of COF-Al interacted with the nitrogen atom (N115) of BGN at the distance of 2.44 Å, while the two hydrogen atoms (H116, H107) of BGN interacted with the oxygen and nitrogen atoms (O74, N112) of COF-Al at distances of 2.05 and 2.11 Å, respectively. Also, the hydrogen atom (H10) of COF-Al interacted with two hydrogen atoms (H122, H118) of MET at distances of 2.50 and 2.44 Å, respectively, whereas the hydrogen atom (H122) of MET also interacted with the hydrogen atom (H25) of COF-Al at a distance of 3.91 Å. The H114 of MET interacts with the O74 of COF-B cavity at a distance of 2.11 Å. The N113 of MET interacts with both H29 and H44 of COF-Al at distances of 2.56 and 2.50 Å. The interaction energy of MET@COF-B complex is far more than that of BGN@COF-B. This may be due to the fact that MET has more interaction sites than BGN. Also MET is a bit bigger than BGN, which best fit into the COF-Al larger cavity as compared with the COF-B cavity.

elements.content: The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) are commonly described as frontier molecular orbitals (FMOs) and their energies are central to investigating the stability and chemical reactivity of molecular substances. Energy gap, which is the difference between the HOMO and LUMO energies, is also essential in charge transfer and sensing tendency in a scheme. The energy gaps values for molecules that are very reactive and less stable are small, while the reverse is true for compounds that are less reactive and stable. The HOMO–LUMO energy gaps of the investigated COF surfaces and their complexes were computed employing ωB97XD/6-311++G (d,p) level of theory as shown in , and distribution patterns of their frontier molecular orbitals are displayed in , respectively. The energy gap (E g) in eV of a scheme can be computed by employing .
elements.clean_text:
HOMO-LUMO Analysis

The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) are commonly described as frontier molecular orbitals (FMOs) and their energies are central to investigating the stability and chemical reactivity of molecular substances. Energy gap, which is the difference between the HOMO and LUMO energies, is also essential in charge transfer and sensing tendency in a scheme. The energy gaps values for molecules that are very reactive and less stable are small, while the reverse is true for compounds that are less reactive and stable. The HOMO-LUMO energy gaps of the investigated COF surfaces and their complexes were computed employing ωB97XD/6-311++G (d,p) level of theory as shown in , and distribution patterns of their frontier molecular orbitals are displayed in , respectively. The energy gap (E g) in eV of a scheme can be computed by employing .

elements.clean_text: 5  HOMO and LUMO of COF-B/COF-Al surfaces and their complexes.

elements.content: There is a change in the electronic properties and conductivities of the complexes after the drug molecule interacts with the COF surfaces. The E HOMO and E LUMO of COF-B surface are −9.31 eV and −0.49 eV, respectively, with E H‑L energy gap of 8.82 eV, while the E HOMO and E LUMO of COF-Al surface are −9.13 eV and −0.15 eV, respectively, with E H‑L energy gap of 9.28 eV. Following the interaction of the pure surfaces with drugs, the orbital densities and energy gaps are altered. The pure surfaces and complexes orbital densities are presented in . The E H‑L energy gaps of BGN@COF-B and MET@COF-B are 8.29 and 7.42 eV, respectively, while the E H‑L energy gaps of BGN@COF-Al and MET@COF-Al are 7.89 and 7.87 eV, respectively. The energy gaps of COF-B complexes are lower than that of pure COF-B. This is as a result of the destabilization of energies of HOMO and stabilization of the energies of the LUMO, which in turn enhance the transfer of charge from HOMO to LUMO. Nonetheless, BGN@COF-B is comparatively less conductive than that of MET@COF-B due to its high energy gap. Likewise, the energy gaps of COF-Al complexes are lower than that of pure COF-Al. This is also due to the destabilization of energies of HOMO and stabilization of the energies of the LUMO, which in turn enhance the transfer of charge from HOMO to LUMO. This result suggested that it is easy to form a chemical bond between COF-B and COF-Al and the drugs (BGN and MET). Nevertheless, MET@COF-Al is slightly more conductive than that of BGN@COF-B due to its low energy gap.

elements.content: Equally, the orbital densities of complexes are as well dissimilar to those of the pristine surfaces. As shown in , the orbital densities of the bare BGN and MET surfaces are distributed equally on HOMO and LUMO. The HOMO orbital densities of the complexes are distributed on the drugs (biguanide and metformin), whereas the LUMO orbital densities are distributed on the surfaces (COF-B and COF-Al). These results indicate that there are charges transfer between the drugs and surfaces. The results show that electronic densities are shifted from the surfaces to the drugs molecules. However, MET@COF-Al significantly draws electronic density comparatively to BNG@COF-B, which is seen in noticeable reduction in energy gap. But, there is no significant difference in the electronic density shift in BGN@COF-Al and MET@COF-Al as indicated in the energy gap difference ( and ).

The relationship between the HOMO/LUMO values of molecular substances and the ionization potential/electron affinity, respectively, are established in and : IP = − H O M O EA = − L U M O

The ionization potential values are 9.31, 9.13, 8.80, 8.17, 7.88, and 7.85 eV for COF-B, COF-Al, BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B, BGN@COF-Al, and MET@COF-Al, respectively. This result agrees with the energy values of HOMO (), which shows that the ionization potential values are directly proportional to the energies of the HOMO values. The interaction of the isolated surfaces with the drugs molecules to form complexes resulted in the destabilization of the HOMO and stabilization of LUMO in all the complexes. The electron affinity values for COF-B, COF-Al, BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B, BGN@COF-Al, and MET@COF-Al are 0.49, −0.15, 0.51, 0.75, −0.01, and −0.02 eV, respectively. The values of electron affinities of the studied systems indicate that the complexes are more reactive than the pristine surfaces that are in line with the ionization potential and electronegativity values. The chemical hardness and softness values for COF-B, COF-Al, BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B, BGN@COF-Al, and MET@COF-Al are 4.41, 4.64, 4.15, 3.71, 3.95, and 3.94 eV (chemical hardness) and 0.113, 0.108, 0.121, 0.135, 0.126, and 0.127 eV–1 (chemical softness), respectively. The low values of chemical softness and high values of chemical hardness point to the fact that the isolated COF surfaces and complexes formed with drugs are naturally stable. The results also agree with the values of electron affinity and chemical potential. Also, high values for electrophilicity index indicate excellent interaction of drug molecules on the COF surfaces.

elements.content: The natural bond orbital analysis is an efficient tool for studying the stabilization energy, hyperconjugation, and charge transfer between the complexes under study. NBO is a computational tool that explains the Schrodinger equation into bonding concepts. The calculations were done at the DFT/ωB97XD/6-311G++ (d, p) level of computation. This allows us investigate the intra- and intermolecular interaction, which is a consequence of the chemical bonds. The NBO also accounts for the electron density and the electron localization between the occupied and unoccupied orbitals. In this study, COF-B and COF-Al and the interaction state with BGN and MFN are investigated through the perturbation of electronic behavior. The stabilization energy for each donor (i) and acceptor (j) orbitals can be expounded in terms of the second order perturbation energy (stabilization energy, E 2). From literature, high E 2 indicates stronger interaction occurring between the donor and acceptor orbital, and the orbitals intensity also constitutes to high stabilization energy. Stabilization energy of most interacting donor orbital and acceptor orbital of the studied complexes was computed using . The larger E 2 value using shows a more donating tendency of donors and the greater conjugation effect of the system: E 2 = Δ E i , j = − q i F 2 i , j ε i − ε j
elements.clean_text:
Natural Bond Orbitals (NBO) Analysis

The natural bond orbital analysis is an efficient tool for studying the stabilization energy, hyperconjugation, and charge transfer between the complexes under study. NBO is a computational tool that explains the Schrodinger equation into bonding concepts. The calculations were done at the DFT/ωB97XD/6-311G++ (d, p) level of computation. This allows us investigate the intra- and intermolecular interaction, which is a consequence of the chemical bonds. The NBO also accounts for the electron density and the electron localization between the occupied and unoccupied orbitals. In this study, COF-B and COF-Al and the interaction state with BGN and MFN are investigated through the perturbation of electronic behavior. The stabilization energy for each donor (i) and acceptor (j) orbitals can be expounded in terms of the second order perturbation energy (stabilization energy, E 2). From literature, high E 2 indicates stronger interaction occurring between the donor and acceptor orbital, and the orbitals intensity also constitutes to high stabilization energy. Stabilization energy of most interacting donor orbital and acceptor orbital of the studied complexes was computed using . The larger E 2 value using  shows a more donating tendency of donors and the greater conjugation effect of the system:  13      E  2   = Δ  E  i , j   = -  q i       F 2    i , j      ε i  -  ε j

elements.content: Each NBO is labeled as being of core (CR), bond (BD), valence lone pair (LP), or extra-valence Rydberg (RY) type, with an affixed asterisk (*) for non-Lewis orbitals. The obtained values for the NBO analysis are tabulated in . From , the highest value of stabilization energy E 2 for BGN was recorded for aluminum-COF compared to boron-COF as 3919.53 kcal/mol from σC2–C4 to σ*C3–H7. In contrast, MFN recorded its highest stabilization energy value with boron-COF as 19587.87 kcal/mol from πB64–O91 to π*B73–O86. Hence, boron-COF with MFN showed the highest E 2 value, which might be due to the better interaction between MFN and the boron-COF surface as similarly reported. The overall increasing trend of E 2 in all of the studied systems is COF-B-MFN > COF-Al-BGN > COF-Al-BGN > COF-Al-MFN. From the above discussion, it is evident that the electronegative nature of boron significantly enhances the stabilization energy of COF-B for the delivery of MFN.

QTAIM is a topology analysis proposed by Bader for the study of intramolecular interaction and bond types existing in a molecule. A critical point offers an insight into the features of the interactions using the topological parameters. The three types of interactions observed in topological analysis include covalent, noncovalent, and partially covalent interactions, with noncovalent nature of interaction subdivided into electrostatic, hydrogen bonding, and van der Waals interactions. Notwithstanding, at critical point, the electron density for the minimum, maximum, or saddle point may be associated with atomic critical point (ACP), bond critical point (BCP), and ring critical point (RCP). Topological parameters like electron density (ρ­(r)), Laplacian of electron density (∇2ρ­(r)), kinetic electron density G(r), potential electron density V(r), bond ellipticity index (ε), and ELF from QTAIM analyses obtained after optimization of the system are presented in . The electron kinetic energy density G(r), the electron potential energy density, and ∇2ρ­(r) are related by the virial theorem stated as follows: 1 4 ∇ 2 ρ ( r ) = 2 G ( r ) + V ( r )
elements.clean_text:
Quantum Theory of Atoms-in-Molecules (QTAIM)

QTAIM is a topology analysis proposed by Bader for the study of intramolecular interaction and bond types existing in a molecule. A critical point offers an insight into the features of the interactions using the topological parameters. The three types of interactions observed in topological analysis include covalent, noncovalent, and partially covalent interactions, with noncovalent nature of interaction subdivided into electrostatic, hydrogen bonding, and van der Waals interactions. Notwithstanding, at critical point, the electron density for the minimum, maximum, or saddle point may be associated with atomic critical point (ACP), bond critical point (BCP), and ring critical point (RCP). Topological parameters like electron density (ρ(r)), Laplacian of electron density (∇2ρ(r)), kinetic electron density G(r), potential electron density V(r), bond ellipticity index (ε), and ELF from QTAIM analyses obtained after optimization of the system are presented in . The electron kinetic energy density G(r), the electron potential energy density, and ∇2ρ(r) are related by the virial theorem stated as follows: 14       1   4     ∇   2   ρ  ( r )  = 2 G  ( r )  + V  ( r )

QTAIM analysis is employed in this investigation to offer a better comprehension of the nature and strength of interaction between the drug molecules and the delivery surfaces. Primarily, the strength of the bond is measured by the electron density (ρ), while the types of interactions are determined by the Laplacian of electron density (∇2ρ) and total electron energy density (H). According to QTAIM theory, noncovalent nature of interaction is indicated by a positive value for Laplacian ∇2ρ­(r), whereas a negative value infers covalent nature of interaction. Notably, from , positive values were reported for all systems suggesting a noncovalent type of interaction. The result evidently indicates a good interaction between the COF surfaces and the drugs. According to reports, ∇22ρ­(r) < 0 and H(r) < 0 denote a covalent (shared) interaction, while noncovalent (closed shell) interactions initiating from weak hydrogen bond, van der Waals interaction, and electrostatic interaction are observed when ∇2ρ­(r) > 0 and H(r) > 0. However, ∇22ρ­(r) > 0 and H(r) < 0 result in a partially covalent interaction. As shown in , a covalent interaction is clearly evident in all the bonds reported during the interaction of the systems, with the highest values of ∇22ρ­(r) observed for N104–H112 (0.8678) in the COF-Al-MFN interaction. The lowest range of shared interaction is reported for H108–H30 bond in the COF-B-MFN system, having a Laplacian value of 0.1129. The energy density value H(r) for N107–C43 bond in the COF-B-MFN (0.9568) interaction appears to be the highest value, and the lowest value was recorded for the N115–H29 (0.1065) in the COF-Al-BGN interaction.

elements.content: ELF value range is always between 0 and 1; however, when ELF has a value >0.5 and <1, it denotes the delocalization of electron density. ELF < 0.5 deduces the presence of a noncovalent (closed shell) interaction, whereas ELF > 0.5 suggests a covalent (shared) interaction between the chemical bonds. Noticeably, the ELF values for COF-B-BGN show that covalent interaction was dominant for the system except for the N109–C46 bond with a value of 0.4873. In contrast, COF-Al-BGN exhibited noncovalent interactions with values between 0.2127 and 0.2694. However, a covalent interaction was reported for the N115–H44 (0.8566) bond. On the other hand, COF-Al-MFN and COF-B-MFN both favored noncovalent interaction with covalent interactions observed at H114–H30 for COF-B-MFN and at H122–H25, H122–H10, and N104–H112 for COF-Al-MFN. The ELF data suggest that COF-B dominantly supports covalent interaction for BGN, while COF-Al interactions with MFN are mostly noncovalent. In addition, the ratio of G(r)/|V|(r) > 1 signifies that the chemical bond interaction is noncovalent in nature, while the covalent (shared) interaction is dominant when G(r)/|V|(r) < 0.5. Similarly, when G(r)/|V|(r) is between 0.5 and 1, a partially covalent interaction is observed. The listed chemical bonds of the systems under investigation are reported to be locked in a covalent interaction implying a good interaction between the covalent framework and the selected drugs. The highest G(r)/|V|(r) value is recorded for the H122–H25 bond in the COF-Al-MFN system with a value of −1.7083. Other bonds had values between −1.1222 and −1.3853, except that of N107–H30 for the COF-B-BGN interaction, which had the lowest G(r)/|V|(r) (−0.3205) value as reported. Bond ellipticity is the topological parameter that provides information on the stability of a bond. A high bond ellipticity value (ε > 1) exhibits that the bond formed during chemical interaction is unstable while a value of ε < 1 denotes a stable chemical bond of interaction. COF-B-BGN favored unstable bond interaction except for the chemical bonds N107–H30 and H105–C58, which were stable compared to the COF-Al-BGN, whose entire system interactions were stable. Similarly, COF-Al-MFN interaction allowed only stable bond interaction in contrast to COF-B-MFN, which recorded unstable interaction at C115–O100 and N107–C43. Therefore, it is noteworthy that COF-Al showed a better performance compared to COF-B for the delivery of BGN and MFN drugs from the topological parameters discussed herein.
elements.clean_text: ELF value range is always between 0 and 1; however, when ELF has a value >0.5 and <1, it denotes the delocalization of electron density. ELF < 0.5 deduces the presence of a noncovalent (closed shell) interaction, whereas ELF > 0.5 suggests a covalent (shared) interaction between the chemical bonds. Noticeably, the ELF values for COF-B-BGN show that covalent interaction was dominant for the system except for the N109-C46 bond with a value of 0.4873. In contrast, COF-Al-BGN exhibited noncovalent interactions with values between 0.2127 and 0.2694. However, a covalent interaction was reported for the N115-H44 (0.8566) bond. On the other hand, COF-Al-MFN and COF-B-MFN both favored noncovalent interaction with covalent interactions observed at H114-H30 for COF-B-MFN and at H122-H25, H122-H10, and N104-H112 for COF-Al-MFN. The ELF data suggest that COF-B dominantly supports covalent interaction for BGN, while COF-Al interactions with MFN are mostly noncovalent. In addition, the ratio of G(r)/|V|(r) > 1 signifies that the chemical bond interaction is noncovalent in nature, while the covalent (shared) interaction is dominant when G(r)/|V|(r) < 0.5. Similarly, when G(r)/|V|(r) is between 0.5 and 1, a partially covalent interaction is observed. The listed chemical bonds of the systems under investigation are reported to be locked in a covalent interaction implying a good interaction between the covalent framework and the selected drugs. The highest G(r)/|V|(r) value is recorded for the H122-H25 bond in the COF-Al-MFN system with a value of -1.7083. Other bonds had values between -1.1222 and -1.3853, except that of N107-H30 for the COF-B-BGN interaction, which had the lowest G(r)/|V|(r) (-0.3205) value as reported. elements.content: The electron localization function is an index proposed by Becke and Edgecombe as a measure of the probability of finding an electron in the neighborhood of another electron with the same spin. The ELF map has been used and certainly will continue to be used with much success to help chemical understanding. A different map of electron localization function is calculated with the help of multiwfn. ELF describes the electronic structure of a molecule by maxima (attractors) and its field localization region (r), which characterizes covalent bonds, lone pairs, nuclear regions, and valence shells in atoms. The valence basins are classified based on their connection to the core basins. In , the blue and dark blue region exhibit a decrease of electron localization function, whereas a half-moon shaped red region shows localized electrons. As reported by Paulis, the exchange repulsive effect and chemical bonding between interacting molecules can be clearly understood from the ELF. Large and small values for ELF are attributed to high and low electron density and also covalent and noncovalent interaction. An ELF value ranging between 0.5 and 1 a.u. suggests regions with bonding and nonbonding localized electrons, whereas an ELF value that is less than 0.5 indicates delocalized electrons. As visualized from and , a slight change in electron density is observed on complexes formed between the drug molecule and COF surfaces. This is in agreement with that reported by Soliman and Abdel for favipiravir and boron nitride nanocages. COF-B-BFN, COF-Al-BGN, and COF-Al-MFN ELF values obtained ranged between 0.5 and 1 a.u. and suggested regions of bonding and nonbonding localized electrons. However, for COF-B-MFN, ELF values obtained are less than 0.5 and indicate regions of delocalized electrons. The presented images of ELF provide information about the transitions occurring from COF surfaces to drug and from drug to COF surfaces as seen in of NBO analysis of the complexes.

Large and small values for ELF are attributed to high and low electron density and also covalent and noncovalent interaction. elements.content: The NCI analysis elucidates noncovalent interactions as well as nonbonding interactions between two molecules via hydrogen interactions. The hydrogen interactions are held strongly by high electronegative atoms, weak hydrogen interactions also known to be van der Waals interactions, and hydrogen repulsions or steric interactions; these interactions are as the result of dipole–dipole interactions formed via transient homogeneities (the act of being the same or comparable) in the electrons with a molecule. NCI can be held by a reduced density gradient (RDG) of molecules. NCI also involves the weak allocation of an electron pair between a hydrogen atom and another atom. This can be associated with noncovalent interaction. However, for a covalent interaction, bonds are formed between two atoms that share electrons between themselves. They are strong and stable, forming the basis for most organic molecules. Noncovalent interactions do not have a shared pair of electrons; instead, atoms attract opposite charges, which makes them significant in biological functions because they are precise without consulting as much rigor as covalent interactions. When there is a weak allocation of electron pairs between a hydrogen atom and another atom, it is seen as a hydrogen bond, but if this attraction tends to exist between groups with opposite electrical charges, its nature of bonding is termed ionic. Eigenvalues that exemplify the oscillation in density can be used to account for the kind of interaction taking place within a given molecule. When the eigenvalue factor (λ2)­ρ denotes values lesser than zero (0), such interaction is repulsive in nature. displays the NCI graph of COF-Al-BGN, COF-B-BGN, COF-Al-MET, and COF-B-MET. The blue ranges from −0.05 to −0.03 a.u., which shows strong attraction (hydrogen bond and halogen bond) of COF (covalent organic framework) with BGN (biguanides) and shows aluminum atom, boron atom in COF-B-BGN, and aluminum in COF-Al-MET; likewise, COF shows boron atom in MET. The green color ranges from – 0.02–0.01 a.u. for COF-Al-BGN, which shows weak hydrogen bond or van der Waals interactions. The red ranges from 0.01 to 0.05 a.u., which characterizes hydrogen repulsion or steric interactions. This finding is consistent with that of Ahsan et al., who discovered that the presence of weak interactions aided the effective delivery of drug molecules to the target site.
elements.clean_text:
Noncovalent Interaction (NCI)

The NCI analysis elucidates noncovalent interactions as well as nonbonding interactions between two molecules via hydrogen interactions. The hydrogen interactions are held strongly by high electronegative atoms, weak hydrogen interactions also known to be van der Waals interactions, and hydrogen repulsions or steric interactions; these interactions are as the result of dipole-dipole interactions formed via transient homogeneities (the act of being the same or comparable) in the electrons with a molecule. NCI can be held by a reduced density gradient (RDG) of molecules. NCI also involves the weak allocation of an electron pair between a hydrogen atom and another atom. This can be associated with noncovalent interaction. However, for a covalent interaction, bonds are formed between two atoms that share electrons between themselves. They are strong and stable, forming the basis for most organic molecules. Noncovalent interactions do not have a shared pair of electrons; instead, atoms attract opposite charges, which makes them significant in biological functions because they are precise without consulting as much rigor as covalent interactions. When there is a weak allocation of electron pairs between a hydrogen atom and another atom, it is seen as a hydrogen bond, but if this attraction tends to exist between groups with opposite electrical charges, its nature of bonding is termed ionic. Eigenvalues that exemplify the oscillation in density can be used to account for the kind of interaction taking place within a given molecule. When the eigenvalue factor (λ2)ρ denotes values lesser than zero (0), such interaction is repulsive in nature.  displays the NCI graph of COF-Al-BGN, COF-B-BGN, COF-Al-MET, and COF-B-MET. The blue ranges from -0.05 to -0.03 a.u., which shows strong attraction (hydrogen bond and halogen bond) of COF (covalent organic framework) with BGN (biguanides) and shows aluminum atom, boron atom in COF-B-BGN, and aluminum in COF-Al-MET; likewise, COF shows boron atom in MET. The green color ranges from - 0.02-0.01 a.u. for COF-Al-BGN, which shows weak hydrogen bond or van der Waals interactions. The red ranges from 0.01 to 0.05 a.u., which characterizes hydrogen repulsion or steric interactions. elements.content: In this present study, the interaction of biguanide and metformin on COF-B and COF-Al was investigated using density functional theory (DFT) calculations at the ωB97XD/6-311++G (d, p) level of theory. Both biguanide and metformin interacted excellently at the different orientations of the electron rich cavity on the COF surfaces. The analysis of the quantum theory of atom in molecules (QTAIM) predicted the nature and strength of interaction between the drug molecule and the COF surfaces. The analysis of the noncovalent interaction (NCI) shows a weak hydrogen bond and steric interactions within the ring of COF surfaces. The computed electronic and structural properties show that both drugs are better adsorbed on the COF surfaces. This finding indicates that it is simple to form a chemical bond between COF-B and COF-Al and the drug molecule biguanide and metformin. However, MET@COF-Al is marginally more conductive than that of BGN@COF-B due to its low energy gap. Also, the results show that electronic densities are shifted from the surfaces to the drugs molecules. The results for stabilization energies obtained after interaction of drug molecule suggest that investigated COF surfaces are stable and can serve as delivery systems for biguanide and metformin. COF-B with MFN had the highest E 2 value, which could be attributed to improved interaction between MFN and the COF surface, as previously reported. COF-B-MFN > COF-Al-BGN > COF-Al-BGN > COF-Al-MFN is the overall increasing trend of E 2 in all of the studied systems. Also, it shows significant charge transfer from the surface to the drug molecules. In addition, the electron localization function (ELF) results were consistent with the transitions occurring in the complexes obtained using the natural bond orbital analysis. The ELF results suggest regions of bonding and nonbonding localized electrons for the complexes formed. From the results for adsorption energies and basis set superposition error (BSSE), BGN is better adsorbed on COF-B with E ads of −65.86 kJ/mol, while MET is better adsorbed on COF-Al with E ads of −47.30 kJ/mol, respectively. Therefore, we suggest that COF-B and COF-Al can serve as a carrier for biguanide and metformin in a drug delivery system.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this present study, the interaction of biguanide and metformin on COF-B and COF-Al was investigated using density functional theory (DFT) calculations at the ωB97XD/6-311++G (d, p) level of theory. Both biguanide and metformin interacted excellently at the different orientations of the electron rich cavity on the COF surfaces. The analysis of the quantum theory of atom in molecules (QTAIM) predicted the nature and strength of interaction between the drug molecule and the COF surfaces. The analysis of the noncovalent interaction (NCI) shows a weak hydrogen bond and steric interactions within the ring of COF surfaces. The computed electronic and structural properties show that both drugs are better adsorbed on the COF surfaces. This finding indicates that it is simple to form a chemical bond between COF-B and COF-Al and the drug molecule biguanide and metformin. However, MET@COF-Al is marginally more conductive than that of BGN@COF-B due to its low energy gap. Also, the results show that electronic densities are shifted from the surfaces to the drugs molecules. The results for stabilization energies obtained after interaction of drug molecule suggest that investigated COF surfaces are stable and can serve as delivery systems for biguanide and metformin. COF-B with MFN had the highest E 2 value, which could be attributed to improved interaction between MFN and the COF surface, as previously reported. COF-B-MFN > COF-Al-BGN > COF-Al-BGN > COF-Al-MFN is the overall increasing trend of E 2 in all of the studied systems. Also, it shows significant charge transfer from the surface to the drug molecules. In addition, the electron localization function (ELF) results were consistent with the transitions occurring in the complexes obtained using the natural bond orbital analysis. The ELF results suggest regions of bonding and nonbonding localized electrons for the complexes formed. From the results for adsorption energies and basis set superposition error (BSSE), BGN is better adsorbed on COF-B with E ads of -65.86 kJ/mol, while MET is better adsorbed on COF-Al with E ads of -47.30 kJ/mol, respectively. Therefore, we suggest that COF-B and COF-Al can serve as a carrier for biguanide and metformin in a drug delivery system.

cln_elements.content:
There is a change in the electronic properties and conductivities of the complexes after the drug molecule interacts with the COF surfaces. The E HOMO and E LUMO of COF-B surface are −9.31 eV and −0.49 eV, respectively, with E H‑L energy gap of 8.82 eV, while the E HOMO and E LUMO of COF-Al surface are −9.13 eV and −0.15 eV, respectively, with E H‑L energy gap of 9.28 eV. Following the interaction of the pure surfaces with drugs, the orbital densities and energy gaps are altered. The pure surfaces and complexes orbital densities are presented in . The E H‑L energy gaps of BGN@COF-B and MET@COF-B are 8.29 and 7.42 eV, respectively, while the E H‑L energy gaps of BGN@COF-Al and MET@COF-Al are 7.89 and 7.87 eV, respectively. The energy gaps of COF-B complexes are lower than that of pure COF-B. This is as a result of the destabilization of energies of HOMO and stabilization of the energies of the LUMO, which in turn enhance the transfer of charge from HOMO to LUMO. Nonetheless, BGN@COF-B is comparatively less conductive than that of MET@COF-B due to its high energy gap. Likewise, the energy gaps of COF-Al complexes are lower than that of pure COF-Al. This is also due to the destabilization of energies of HOMO and stabilization of the energies of the LUMO, which in turn enhance the transfer of charge from HOMO to LUMO. This result suggested that it is easy to form a chemical bond between COF-B and COF-Al and the drugs (BGN and MET). Nevertheless, MET@COF-Al is slightly more conductive than that of BGN@COF-B due to its low energy gap.

The ionization potential values are 9.31, 9.13, 8.80, 8.17, 7.88, and 7.85 eV for COF-B, COF-Al, BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B, BGN@COF-Al, and MET@COF-Al, respectively. This result agrees with the energy values of HOMO (), which shows that the ionization potential values are directly proportional to the energies of the HOMO values. The interaction of the isolated surfaces with the drugs molecules to form complexes resulted in the destabilization of the HOMO and stabilization of LUMO in all the complexes. The electron affinity values for COF-B, COF-Al, BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B, BGN@COF-Al, and MET@COF-Al are 0.49, −0.15, 0.51, 0.75, −0.01, and −0.02 eV, respectively. The values of electron affinities of the studied systems indicate that the complexes are more reactive than the pristine surfaces that are in line with the ionization potential and electronegativity values. The chemical hardness and softness values for COF-B, COF-Al, BGN@COF-B, MET@COF-B, BGN@COF-Al, and MET@COF-Al are 4.41, 4.64, 4.15, 3.71, 3.95, and 3.94 eV (chemical hardness) and 0.113, 0.108, 0.121, 0.135, 0.126, and 0.127 eV–1 (chemical softness), respectively. The low values of chemical softness and high values of chemical hardness point to the fact that the isolated COF surfaces and complexes formed with drugs are naturally stable. The results also agree with the values of electron affinity and chemical potential. Also, high values for electrophilicity index indicate excellent interaction of drug molecules on the COF surfaces.
